text: A COUPLE moves down a walkway, deep in subdued conversati All around them trees explode with autumn color. Birds si Their path is dappled with leafy shadow. To their left, on the sunny meadow, TEENAGERS throw sauce and footballs, smoke cigarettes and joints, drink beer an soda, savoring the waning hours of summer.

He is WILLS KEANE, late 40's to early 50's, strikingly  handsome, impeccably dressed, and supremely poised. At fi glance he has the proud glow of a hedonist who in the war against time has been the undisputed victor. Only a closer look hints at the toll of battle. His shoul strain under the weight of so much repetition. His eyes a touched by regret. The lines in his face reveal an emergi disenchantment not so much with the world as with himself Walking at his side is a WOMAN, 30, attractive and bright Her name is unimportant because so many have come before and, if the past prevails, so many will come after. She listens intently, as Wills finishes speaking --
-- and I could have waited to tell  you, but I wanted to leave no room  for misunderstanding.
Well, you certainly didn't.
Still talking quietly, they pass into a more secluded are of the park--
No, I see how you could feel this  way. Of course I do. It's human. But  what I don't get is why you'd want  to announce it so quickly. I mean,  we just met. Feelings change. You  don't even know me.
Yes, I do.
She is amused by his confidence --
Oh, really?
The minute I laid eyes on you. It's  the saddest thing about getting older.  You know people so quickly. I even  knew you'd end up hating me.
Well, you're wrong. I don't.
(with a weary smile) Give it time.

She laughs. Then he stops. He hears something. She stops. She hears it, too. It's a GIRL'S VOICE. He casually turns and looks, squinting into the sun. He takes a few steps and there, between trees, he sees TW DOZEN PEOPLE sitting on the grass and on folding chairs - most are middle-aged or older with a distinctly intellect bohemian look to them. Standing and addressing them is CHARLOTTE FIELDING, 19, f willowy, pale, lovely in an unconventional way. She wears eccentric hat and a vintage dress. Her bearing is upright her gaze warm and intelligent, her voice rich with emotio

-- and for weeks I sat by her bed  and cried. I told her I loved her  and I begged her not to leave me.  All I could think about was what I'd  lose if she died. And then one  night... she was in really bad pain...  I stopped thinking about myself for  a second and I thought about her. (fighting tears) I stopped crying. I said goodbye.  And in less than an hour Ella was  gone.
The woman whispers in Wills' ear --
It's so sad.
But Wills ignores her. He watches Charlotte with keen  interest, touched by the depth and sincerity of her emoti
I really think it's possible to hold  a person back... cry them back...  from dying. That's what I did to  Ella and I'll never do it to anyone  else again. (softly) I hope no one ever does it to me.
She looks out at the group, many of whom are crying. A te runs down her cheek. She smiles and wipes it away. The woman, seeing Wills' interest in the girl, whispers -
So what do you know about her?
He knows a great deal. Or at least he thinks he does. But his answer is nonchalant --
That she's just a kid.

He takes the woman gently by the elbow and guides her awa He steals one last look back. Charlotte, returning to where she was sitting, notices Wi Their eyes meet and a charge passes between them. Meanwhile an OLD MAN has risen from his chair --
I met Ella at City College in 1938...
Wills slowly turns and walks away.

A SWARM OF PEDESTRIANS ascends the steps to the bustling  street. FIND CHARLOTTE amid the swarm, struggling with a load of  BOXES and SHOPPING BAGS, carrying an antique, wood-and-wi DRESSMAKER'S MANNEQUIN. She wears a peasant dress with a cycle jacket, a backpack and another eccentric hat.
Charlotte makes her way down the leaf-strewn pathway. Whe the mannequin by the neck, she passes NYU STUDENTS smokin laughing, and chatting on their way to class.
Charlotte hauls the mannequin down the block. A YOUNG MAN offers her assistance, but she politely and firmly refuse
Charlotte wearily hauls the mannequin across the cobblest street, over the curb, and up to the stoop of a charming slightly dilapidated BROWNSTONE.
Charlotte opens the door into the darkness. She hits a li switch and nothing happens. She flips it back and forth -
Shit.
She dumps her boxes and bags, then wheels in the mannequi
Dolly! The bulb burned out!
EIGHT SILHOUETTES are crouched in the dark room. The mant is draped with a HAPPY BIRTHDAY BANNER. The coffee table stacked with WRAPPED GIFTS.
Charlotte looks suspiciously at the living room door --
Dolly?
She tiptoes through the darkness and lays her ear against it.
We hear chuckles and whispers of anticipation. An older  woman's raspy, boozy voice growls --
My ass hurts.
A few people chuckle, but they're quickly hushed. The DOO KNOB TURNS and the DOOR OPENS. Everyone leaps up in a bla of light --
SURPRISE!

The MANNEQUIN bursts into the room, teetering crazily, we CHARLOTTE'S JACKET, BACKPACK, and HAT. Everyone FLINCHES and SCREAMS. Amid a chorus of laughter, Charlotte enters. Grinning, she wags a facetious finger -
See? Surprises suck!

An antique clock ticks crisply on the dresser. Wills stan before a mahogany mirror, buttoning a freshly laundered w shirt. Lying on the cradle bed, half-wrapped in a sheet, naked b for a string of pearls, is TANYA, 35, raven-haired, much thin. She smokes a cigarette.
Oh, Wills, please, not again. It's  our third date and we're already in  a rut.
But I thought you loved it.

She stretches with her cigarette but before she can make to the ashtray, her ASH FALLS on a New York magazine. On the cover is a PHOTOGRAPH OF WILLS standing next to a  YOUNG CHEF in a fashionable restaurant. The caption reads "The Prodigal Son Returns."
Oh, I do -- except for the fact that  there isn't a single thing on the  menu I can eat.
(with a chuckle) Sure, there is; there's just very  little you're willing to digest.
He slips in a cuff link. She affects a breezy indifferenc
Fine then. We'll go, I'll get big,  fat, and horrible, and it'll serve  you right.
Wills slips on a silk tie --
No, it won't. Because it takes at  least a few weeks to get fat and by  then you won't even be speaking to  me.
(curiously) Why do you say that?
He stops tying his tie and stares at her in the mirror --
Because we have no future. All I can  offer you is this... what we have  right now... nothing more  meaningful... until it ends.
He goes back to tying his tie, then adds softly --
I could have waited to tell you, but  I wanted to leave no room for  misunderstanding.
She stares at him, speechless.
Its decor is exquisitely tasteful, its ambiance warm and  convivial. The night is in full swing. Most of the tables are taken and the bar is packed.

From amid the RUSH OF TRAFFIC, a TAXI breaks free and gli to the curb in front of the RESTAURANT. Its facade is windowless. Only a small brass plaque on th grey marble reveals that this is ELYSIUM. Wills and ERIKO, 30's, Japanese, aloof and stunning, emer from the taxi, elegantly dressed, and move to the front d

TWO TIPSY DEBUTANTES pass Wills and Eriko as they enter. recognizes Wills and smiles flirtatiously. Wills stops and helps Eriko off with her jacket. JESUS, 3 the dashing Cuban-American maitre d', superbly discreet,  approaches --
Good evening, Mr. Keane. Will you be  dining with us tonight?
We certainly will. Table seven, Jesus,  if it's available.
Yes, sir.
Wills hands Eriko's jacket to MELISSA, 20, the hat check  girl --
How are you, Melissa?
(blushing) Fine, Mr. Keane.
CELIA, mid-20's, the chipper, blonde Midwestern hostess,  arrives, wearing a stunned, glassy smile.
Good evening, Celia. And how --
(with forced cheeriness) Just dandy, sir, thanks!
Table seven.
This way, please.
Celia, barely making eye contact with Eriko, walks quickl away. Wills is amused and a little confused by Celia's  behavior. He lays a hand on Eriko's back --
I'll be right with you.

Eriko nods and follows Celia. Wills moves to the reservation stand where his best frien and the restaurant's manager, JOHN VOLPE, 40, a brilliant dapper, tough as nails Brooklynite stands, listening to  someone on the telephone. Wills lays a hand on his shoulder and mutters into his ea
How's it going?
(covering the phone) Chaos.
The house specialty.
Easy for you to say, ya prick.  Waltzin' in here like you own the  joint.
Wills laughs and takes a look into the bar. John gestures with his head in Eriko's direction --
So who's the new potential ex-wife?  I thought you were still wastin'  time with Tanya-von-What's-her-name.
We wisely agreed to cut our losses.

Wills exits into the bar. John smiles and shakes his head FOLLOW WILLS, as he glides along the bar. CUSTOMERS and S greet him warmly. As he enters the main dining room, DINERS spot him --  sprinkled among them are CELEBRITIES from every walk of c life. Wills greets them, stopping to shake their hands an kiss their cheeks. Suddenly, Celia, the hostess, red-faced, blocks his path

Look, I have no right to say this,  okay? And you can fire me if you  want, but in the six weeks we've  been open you've brought in six  different women -- tonight makes  seven -- and it's really starting to  get to me.
In what way?
I have to greet them! It's like  working at a dog shelter! I'm afraid  to learn their names or even smile  at them because I know any minute  they could be put down!
I assure you it's an absolutely  painless procedure.
Shocked, she can't help but sputter a laugh --
It is?
Sure. (beat) Especially for me.
They both laugh. He moves closer, lowers his voice, and s with warm sincerity --
Actually, I appreciate your concern,  Celia. The truth is I'm a little  worried myself.
Seriously?
Seriously. I've been trying to do  better. (uneasily) But... you know how it is... old  habits die hard.
So I'm not fired?
Nope. In fact, John's been looking  for an assistant. Tell him you've  just been promoted.

Wills smiles, pats her in the shoulder, and moves on. She can't believe it. A WAITER carrying a BIRTHDAY CAKE -- blazing with candles and decorated with a WOMAN'S HAT made of MERINGUE LATTICE passes by on his way to the REAR DINING ROOM. From inside, VOICES begin to sing HAPPY BIRTHDAY. Wills, curiosity piqued, follows.

The waiter sets down the cake at the center of a round ta There's a CHEER and APPLAUSE as the song ends. Wills cann see whose birthday it is because the waiter blocks his vi Just as Wills is about to exit the room, the waiter steps away. Wills glances over and sees the birthday girl. At f he can't place her, but then he does, and his face soften and brightens. It's Charlotte. She wears a black velvet dress and a  wonderfully eccentric hat. Her eyes glow in the candlelig Through the chorus of voices, urging her to make a wish, cries out --
You guys! Let me think! (concentrating) Okay. Okay.

Charlotte blows hard, and, with a little more effort than you might expect, extinguishes the candles. Everyone APPL and CHEERS. To Charlotte's right sits SIMON LORING, late 20's, Englis sardonic, adoring. He gestures at her CHEST and says --
Watch carefully, everyone -- they  ought to begin emerging any moment  now.
Everyone laughs. Charlotte playfully slaps him --
Very funny! Actually, any moment now  you're gonna turn straight and fall  at my feet.
Oh, darling, you know I would if I  could.
Charlotte's best friend, SHANNON HARRIS, 19, a spoiled bu big-hearted redhead, drowning in curls, mutters --
The only time he falls at your feet  now is when he wants to borrow your  Prada loafers.

More laughter. BACK TO WILLS. He considers approaching Charlotte, but th he looks back and sees Eriko sitting alone at their table idly stabbing at her drink with a straw. Regretting his rudeness, he takes a step toward her, but  then hears --
Is that Wills Keane?
He turns and sees DOLORES TALBOT, 70, blonde wig, spindly frame, weathered skin, large, sad eyes. She holds a mixed drink --
It sure as hell is and he hasn't  changed a bit!
I'm sorry, do I --
You little fool, it's Dolores Talbot.  Dolly!
His smile shows uneasy surprise --
My God, it is.
Yeah, I know, time's kicked my ass  but good. Come on, Romeo, let's bury  the hatchet. Give me a hug. Careful  of the cocktail.
As he hugs Dolores, he can't help but look over at Charlo again.
So what the hell're you doin' around  here? Last I heard you were out in  earthquake country blowin' the family  fortune.
Actually, I doubled it.
Good for you!
ON CHARLOTTE. She looks over. Her view is such that she s Wills but not Dolores. A faint blush creeps into Charlotte's cheeks. She pretend to listen as Shannon tells a story --
-- and you know how bouncer's get.  He's like, "That's the worst fake  I.D. I've ever seen." And I'm like,  "Yeah? Well, you have the worst dread- extensions!" And then just when --
Noticing Charlotte's distraction, Simon whispers calmly t her --
Are you feeling all right? You look  positively green.
Charlotte speaks under her breath without moving her lips
He's here. And he's staring at me  again.
No way!
Both Shannon and Simon turn to look, but like lightning  Charlotte grabs them both --
Don't! (to Simon) Wait a few seconds, then go to the  bathroom.
How will I know him?
He's beautiful. And much older.
Really? (getting up) If he's rich you might have a fight  on your hands.
Charlotte watches furtively as Simon rises from his chair and walks over. As he passes Wills, he flashes him a sedu smile. Wills is confused by it.
Okay, look.
Shannon swivels her head and throws an aloof, vacant star in Wills' direction. Then she looks back at Charlotte, mo agape --
He's as old as my dad!
Charlotte laughs. BACK ON WILLS. He does his best to be attentive as Dolore exhales a plume of smoke into his face --
Sure, L.A.'s okay if you're a cactus  or a lizard, but if you're a New  Englander, your soul dries up and  blows away like a god damn leaf.
It only took me twenty years to come  to my senses.
So what're you doin' now? You owned  some restaurants out there, didn't  you?
ON CHARLOTTE. She sits listening to Shannon --
And so, after all that, we pay our  cover, we get in, and it's totally  heinous! Nothing but losers and --
Charlotte looks over and pales, her eyes widening --
Oh, shit.
What?
Dolores walks up, hauling Wills by the arm --
Kids! I want you to meet an old chum  of mine, the owner of this fine  establishment -- Wills Keane!
The table greets him. Wills, slightly self-conscious, loo at everyone but Charlotte.
And that over there's the birthday  girl -- my granddaughter, Charlotte.
The news hits Wills hard. But he does his best to hide it He musters a casual smile --
Not Katie and Jay's daughter?
You bet. She got her height from her  dad. But her talent's all Katie's.
Dolores indicates the hat that Charlotte's wearing --
Made it herself from scratch. That  one, too. (to Shannon) Honey, show 'im.
Shannon makes an elaborate comic show of modeling the hat she's wearing. The table laughs. Wills levels his gaze at Charlotte --
Impressive.
Try as she might to accept the compliment with grace,  Charlotte can't help but grin.
Thanks.
The WINE STEWARD stands at a station on which sit TWO BOT OF CHAMPAGNE on ice. He reaches for one. Wills stops him
I think we can do better than that.
The steward, understanding, nods and departs, taking the  champagne with him.
Happy birthday, Charlotte.
Thanks.
(under her breath) Twenty years old and never been...
(laughing) Shut up!
Amused, he flashes Charlotte his most dazzling smile.
I'll let you get back to your  celebration. (kissing Dolly's cheek) A pleasure to see you again.
Same here.
Wills turns to exit. Simon, returning to his seat, murmur seductively to Wills as he passes by --
Leaving so soon?
Wills looks at him, confused again, then continues on. As Simon sits, he mutters to Charlotte --
Be still my beating heart. (beat) Or is that your heart?
(whisper to Charlotte) You're not really into him, are you?
Charlotte turns to Dolores who has just sat down.
Hey, Dolly, how do you know him?
(uneasily) From Newport. Old friend of your  mom's.
Dolores eats a sloppy forkful of birthday cake.
A gentle breeze tickles a white lace curtain. A PHONE RIN

Charlotte, standing in the small antiquated kitchen, wear flannel pajamas, tenses when she hears the PHONE RINGING  UPSTAIRS. She snatches an apple from a bowl and dashes ou of the room. FOLLOW CHARLOTTE running through the DINING ROOM... into LIVING ROOM... into the FOYER... and up a DARK STAIRCASE.
A startling clash of childhood, adolescence, and womanhoo Everything from stuffed animals to posters of pop icons t volumes of great literature.
Charlotte bangs in, flings herself on the bed, and grabs phone --
Okay, bitch, I'm ready!
Wills sits in his woolen robe, holding a portable phone.  Amused, he smiles into the morning sun --
For what?
Oh my God, I'm so sorry! Wait. Who  is this?
Wills Keane.
Her heart stops. She sits up slowly, her body tensed.
Who did you think it was?
My friend Simon, actually. He always  calls me the morning after to sort  of... you know... sum everything up.
And how would you sum it up,  Charlotte? Turning twenty.
Kinda cool, kinda creepy. Anyway,  you wanna speak to my grandmother?
(with a chuckle) I don't think so.

OLIVIA, 30's, Wills' Jamaican cook and housekeeper, enter Plump, handsome, and perpetually amused, she carries a tr laden with continental breakfast and a New York Times. Wi mouths a greeting. She smiles back and sets the tray on a table.
I called because I'm going to be  attending a benefit... a black-and- white ball.... and I'd like you to  design a hat... for my date.
Really? Wow. Sounds fun. Okay.
It's a gift. I don't have her  measurements, but she's about your  size. What're you, a six?
Uh-huh.
Good -- then let's assume your hat  size is also the same.
But that doesn't necessarily --
It's a risk we'll just have to take.
Charlotte runs over to her sewing table, looking for a pe and paper. She finds paper, but no pen --
Her dress is a sheath... sleeveless,  black. The hat must, of course, be  black or white or both.
She finds a pen but it doesn't work. She grabs an eyeline and uses that --
Any particular style?
(sipping his coffee) No, just plenty of it. How long will  it take?
A week or two.
You have till Thursday. I'll need it  here by seven o'clock. I'm at the  Pembroke on Central Park West and  76th.
Oh. Wow. Okay.
What's your fee?
(faltering) I don't really have one. I usually  just make them for friends.
How's five hundred dollars?
Really? Wow.
Charlotte?
His tone has abruptly shifted; it's intimately hushed. It both daunts and excites her --
Yeah?
You say "wow" a lot.
I know.
It has to stop. You're a woman now.
I know.
Bye.
Bye.

She clicks off the phone, wilts into a swoon on the bed, breaks out laughing. Wills, still holding the receiver, stares dreamily into t middle distance. He snaps to when Olivia enters. Her accent is as much Que as it is Caribbean --
See, now you got me worried.
What do you mean?
You slept alone last night. You must  be sick or somethin'. You want me to  call a doctor?
Thank you, no, I'm fine.
She throws him a sly, sidelong glance, then exits. Wills  laughs and contentedly sips his coffee. FROM THE NEXT SCENE, we hear the sound of SQUEALING, LAUG SHOUTING CHILDREN.
Surrounded by swarming PARENTS and KIDS, Wills stands wit John, the manager of Elysium, and his wife, SARAH VOLPE, who, gazing out of frame, keeps a watchful eye on their k
Save it, pal! Don't even bother! I  may not have gone to a fancy school  like Bendover --
(to Sarah) That would be Andover.
Sure, if his folks could have afforded  it.
-- but when Wills Keane comps three  bottles of Dom to a twenty-year-old  girl, then tells me he did it 'cause  he likes the kid's grandma, I smell  a rat!
(looking around) Oh, is that what that is? I figured  there was a dirty diaper somewhere.
(lightly) Okay, I admit it, she interests me.
(turning to Sarah) He's gonna do it! I don't believe  it! He moved us back here for nothing!
So much for that turned leaf.
(amused) Come on, you're overreacting.

Is that what you think? Buddy, since  we hit town, I have done nothin' but  cut you slack! Every week a new woman  on your arm and I didn't say a word.  Why? 'Cause I figured at least they're  in the right demographic. Maybe by  accident you'll trip over something  substantial. But this little girl?  Best she could be is Miss Right's  daughter!
(uneasily) I know. It's just that there's  something about her. She's special...  and I just thought --
"She's young. She's hot. I'm on the  verge of menopause. Why not go for  it?"
Wills and Sarah meet eyes.
There wouldn't be much point in lying  to you, would there?
Sarah shakes her head.
Mommy, Daddy, look, look!
MOLLY and CARLA, the Volpes' five-year-old TWIN DAUGHTERS run up, beaming, each carrying a huge stuffed animal.
Hey, they're bigger than you are!
John scoops both his daughters up in his arms and kisses  them repeatedly. Wills watches, his eyes filling with a vague, wistful env He sees Sarah staring at him. She smiles sympathetically.

The furniture is antique and dark. The white walls are ti with yellow from years of cigarettes. In one corner, the  paint has chipped off the ceiling in a jagged plate. Dolores sits on a worn-out leather arm chair, smoking, si a cocktail, watching a DAYTIME TALK SHOW. In the background, we see Charlotte working in the ADJOIN DINING ROOM which she has turned into a lovely sewing roo CLOSER ON CHARLOTTE. She builds her hat on a HAT BLOCK -- wooden mannequin head. Strewn all around her are the mate of her hatmaking -- bolts of cloth, hat blocks, a sewing  table. Shannon, wearing sweats and a T-shirt, lies on the floor, eating M+M's and drinking diet soda, while heavily markin up a text book with a YELLOW HIGHLIGHTER. Charlotte stops and rubs her eyes, then she glances down Shannon and smiles --
Why don't you mark what isn't  important? That way you'll save ink.
Why don't you sew your mouth to my  butt? That way you'll stop annoying  me.
They both laugh. Overhearing, Dolores croaks facetiously
Now, now, if you two kids can't play  nice --
Shannon rolls over onto her back --
God, I hate school.
Charlotte pins a strip of black lace to the hat --
Oh, come on, just last week, you  said you were on a roll. You loved  it!
Well, now I'm on the rag and I hate  it.
Charlotte chuckles and sets the half-finished hat on her  head. Still seated, she wheels her work chair over to a m
I think you're incredibly lucky. I'd  love to be going to college.
Shannon rolls over and looks at her. Suddenly her express is inexplicably solemn --
Am I the most spoiled brat in the  world or what?
Spoiled brats don't even ask questions  like that. (re: the hat) What do you think?
She models the hat. Tears well in Shannon's eyes and she  says without even a hint of irony or sentimentality --
That you're the most beautiful person  in the entire world.
Charlotte smiles, looks away, and, trying not to cry, fus with the hat.
A cold autumn rain falls. The Irish doorman, MICHAEL, 60' melancholy, stoop-shouldered, smokes a cigarette, looking at the unburdening sky. A LIMOUSINE pulls up. The passenger window glides down --
Mikey! How ya doin'?
A bit early, aren't you?
Hey, in this soup, better safe than  sorry, you know what I mean?

RUNNING FOOTSTEPS approach. Michael looks. The driver loo too. It's Charlotte, dressed in tattered jeans, a light rain c and sneakers, dashing at breakneck speed down the street, carrying something in a GARBAGE BAG.
KEANE!
She runs right past Michael --
Michael works the shiny brass controls. Charlotte, winded hair dripping wet, watches the numbers tick by overhead.  Michael smiles at her with paternal fondness --
He's goin' to a fancy party tonight.
Charlotte, nonplused by his lack of discretion, smiles  politely --
Oh, really?
The elevator doors open.
Watch your step, Miss.
Thank you.

She emerges, moves to Wills' door, and waits for the elev to close. When it does, she hurries back to a table over  which hangs a GILDED MIRROR. She takes a LOVELY OLD HAT BOX out of the garbage bag and ditches the bag under the table. Then she quickly checks  herself in the glass. She doesn't like what she sees. She pokes at her sopping  hair and squeezes it, but it's hopeless. Remembering the  time, she hurries back to the door, takes a deep breath, rings the bell. She waits. And waits. Then she hears footsteps approachin She realizes she's left the hat box on the table. She rushes over and grabs it, just in time to get back to the door when it OPENS. Olivia, the housekeeper, steps out, wearing her coat and  carrying her purse. Her voice is low and gentle --
He's waitin' for you, Miss Fieldin'.
They exchange cordial smiles. Charlotte enters.
Charlotte steps into a dim hallway lined with oil paintin carpeted with a Persian runner, and lighted by three anti sconces. She walks slowly, terribly self-conscious.
The room is vast, furnished with antiques, decorated with the same masculine good taste. Charlotte enters timidly,  then hears --
What happened?
She looks and sees Wills standing, back turned, before a  broad set of high windows. City lights glimmer in the  distance; beneath them lies the vast gloom of Central Par
I couldn't get a cab, so I took the  subway... only it was an express and  it didn't stop at --
You realize, don't you, that you're  a full eighteen minutes late?
I know... I'm so sorry... I --
Wills turns around. A magnificent figure -- expertly tail tux, every hair in place, freshly manicured. And then he  offers her an amused, reassuring smile --

Charlotte, relax. What's the point  of being a beautiful young woman if  it isn't to keep your admirers  waiting? In fact, you disappoint me:  I was looking forward to at least  another half hour of suspense.
Flattered, her face brightens --
I could leave and come back.
Nope, too late. Anyway, I want to  see the hat.
He walks over to her. Smiling, she sets down the box, unt the ribbon, and gingerly removes the hat. It's sublimely  simple and elegant. She looks at him with hope. His face  betrays nothing --
Try it on.
I can't. I'm soaked.
It's all right.

Charlotte, a little confused, carefully sets the hat on h head. She steps to a wall mirror, pulls the veil down, an sets it at the correct angle. Wills appears behind her and shares the reflection. She f his presence, hears his breathing. They speak in hushed t
It's perfect. It's like a tiny  sculpture.
I wanted it to be a tiny poem.
She smiles. Their eyes meet in the glass.
If only I had some use for it. (off her look) My date canceled a few hours ago.
Why?
I don't know. She was vague. Would  you... like to come in her place?
Charlotte can't believe it. She smiles at his reflection.
Like this?
The outfit I bought her is hanging  in the guest room closet.
(anxiously) It's okay? Are you sure?
(amused) Of course.
He gestures toward the half-open door on other side of th room. Charlotte turns and, biting her lip, looks at the d then back at Wills, then back at the door.

A spectacular affair is in full swing, a benefit for the  METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART attended by FIVE HUNDRED GUEST from HIGH SOCIETY dressed only in black and white. A LARGE BAND plays -- everything from waltzes to jazz to  swing. Chandeliers glisten. Guests, sitting in ornate box look down on the marble dance floor where a WALTZ is in  progress. FIND WILLS AND CHARLOTTE, dancing together. Charlotte loo sophisticated and beautiful beyond measure, wearing a  sleeveless black sheath with a fake fur wrap, and, of cou her hat.
Nonsense. You're very good. Where  did you learn?
From Ella. The woman whose memorial  you crashed.
So you did see me there.
Uh-huh. And the next time I saw you,  you were on the cover of New York  magazine. And I had to pick a place  for my birthday. So...

It takes a few beats for Wills to put it together. He smi realizing that her presence at Elysium wasn't a coinciden She smiles back, sweetly, coyly.
